It was founded in 1870 and grew through multiple acquisitions, including [[Disconto-Gesellschaft]] in 1929 (as a consequence of which it was known from 1929 to 1937 as '''Deutsche Bank und Disconto-Gesellschaft''' or "DeDi-Bank"),{{citation |title=German Banking between the Wars: The Crisis of the Credit Banks |author=Theo Balderston |journal=Business History Review |date=1991 |volume=65:3 |pages=554-605 |publisher=Harvard College |url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/3116768 }}{{rp|580}} [[Bankers Trust]] in 1998, and [[Deutsche Postbank]] in 2010. As of 2018, the bank's network spanned 58 countries with a large presence in Europe, the Americas, and Asia.{{Cite web |last=Deutsche Bank |title=Deutsche Bank Location Finder |url=https://www.db.com/company/en/location-finder.htm?kid=lf.inter-en.redirect |access-date=26 May 2018 |website=Deutsche Bank |archive-date=26 May 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180526112925/https://www.db.com/company/en/location-finder.htm?kid=lf.inter-en.redirect |url-status=dead }} As of 2021, Deutsche Bank was the [[List of largest banks|21st largest bank]] in the world by total assets and 93rd in the world by market capitalization.{{Cite web |date=30 June 2017 |title=Top 50 Largest Banks in the World |url=http://www.relbanks.com/worlds-top-banks/assets |access-date=26 May 2018 |publisher=relbanks.com}} It is a component of the [[DAX]] stock market index, and often referred to as the [[List of banks in Germany|largest German banking institution]] even though the [[Sparkassen-Finanzgruppe]] comes well ahead in terms of combined assets. Deutsche Bank has been designated as a global [[Systemically important financial institution|systemically important bank]] by the [[Financial Stability Board]] since 2011. Deutsche Bank is a [[universal bank]] with four major divisions: Investment Bank, Corporate Bank, Private Bank and Asset Management (DWS). Its investment banking operations often command substantial [[deal flow]]. According to the ''New Yorker'', Deutsche Bank has long had an "abject" reputation among major banks, as it has been involved in major scandals across different issue areas.{{Cite magazine |date=2020-09-23 |title=The FinCEN Files Shed New Light on a Scandalous Episode at Deutsche Bank |url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/the-fincen-files-shed-new-light-on-a-scandalous-episode-at-deutsche-bank |access-date=2022-03-02 |magazine=The New Yorker |language=en-US}} ==History== [[File:Deutsche Bank building - Sydney.jpg|thumb|180px|Deutsche Bank, Sydney]] [[File:Deutsche Bank 1881.jpg|thumb|Share of the Deutsche Bank, issued 2. November 1881]] ===1870–1919=== Deutsche Bank was founded on 1870 in [[Berlin]] as a specialist bank for financing foreign trade and promoting German exports.For the history of Deutsche Bank, in general, see [[Lothar Gall]] (et al.), The Deutsche Bank 1870–1995, London (Weidenfeld & Nicolson) 1995.{{Cite web |last=James |first=Harold |title=Deutsche Bank Isn't Deutsch Anymore |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/02/24/deutsche-bank-uber-alles/ |access-date=2018-11-20 |website=Foreign Policy |language=en}} It subsequently played a large part in developing Germany's financial services industry, as its business model focused on providing finance to industrial customers. The bank's statute was adopted on 22 January 1870, and on 10 March 1870 the [[Prussia]]n government granted it a banking license. The statute laid great stress on foreign business: {{blockquote|The object of the company is to transact banking business of all kinds, in particular, to promote and facilitate trade relations between Germany, other European countries and overseas markets.Statut der Deutschen Bank Aktien-Gesellschaft, Berlin 1870, pp. 3–4.|sign=|source=}} Three of the founders were Georg Siemens, whose father's cousin had founded [[Werner von Siemens|Siemens and Halske]]; [[Adelbert Delbrück]] and [[Ludwig Bamberger]]. Prior to the founding of Deutsche Bank, German importers and exporters were dependent upon British and French banking institutions in the world markets—a serious handicap in that German [[Bill of exchange|bills]] were almost unknown in international commerce, generally disliked and subject to a higher rate of a discount than English or French bills.{{Americana|wstitle=Deutsche Bank, The|inline=1}} ==== Founding members ==== * [[Hermann Zwicker]] (Bankhaus Gebr. Schickler, Berlin) * [[Anton Adelssen]] (Bankhaus Adelssen & Co., Berlin) * [[Adelbert Delbrück]] (Bankhaus Delbrück, Leo & Co.) * [[Heinrich von Hardt]] (Hardt & Co., Berlin, New York) * [[Ludwig Bamberger]] (politician, former chairman of Bischoffsheim, Goldschmidt & Co) * [[Victor Freiherr von Magnus]] (Bankhaus F. Mart Magnus) * {{Interlanguage link multi|Adolph vom Rath|de}} (Bankhaus Deichmann & Co., Cologne) * [[Gustav Kutter]] (Bankhaus Gebrüder Sulzbach, Frankfurt) * Gustav Müller (Württembergische Vereinsbank, Stuttgart) ==== First directors ==== * Wilhelm Platenius, [[Georg von Siemens|Georg Siemens]] and [[Hermann Wallich]] The bank's first domestic branches, inaugurated in 1871 and 1872, were opened in [[Bremen]]Manfred Pohl / Angelika Raab-Rebentisch, Die Deutsche Bank in Bremen 1871–1996, Munich, Zurich (Piper) 1996. and [[Hamburg]].Manfred Pohl / Angelika Raab-Rebentisch, Die Deutsche Bank in Hamburg 1872–1997, Munich, Zurich (Piper) 1997. Its first oversea-offices opened in Shanghai in 1872Deutsche Bank in China, Munich (Piper) 2008. and London in 1873Manfred Pohl / [[Kathleen Burk]], ''Deutsche Bank in London 1873–1998'', Munich, Zurich (Piper) 1998. followed by South American offices between 1874 and 1886.{{Cite book |last=James |first=H |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gArOx8n77JIC&q=Deutsche+Bank |title=The Nazi Dictatorship and the Deutsche Bank |date=13 September 2004 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=0521838746 |access-date=11 July 2012}} The branch opening in London, after one failure and another partially successful attempt, was a prime necessity for the establishment of credit for the German trade in what was then the world's money center. Major projects in the early years of the bank included the [[Northern Pacific Railroad]] in the USChristopher Kobrak, Banking on Global Markets. Deutsche Bank and the United States, 1870 to the Present, New York (Cambridge University Press) 2008. and the [[Baghdad Railway]]A Century of Deutsche Bank in Turkey, Istanbul 2008, pp. 21–27. (1888). In Germany, the bank was instrumental in the financing of bond offerings of steel company [[Krupp]] (1879) and introduced the chemical company [[Bayer]] to the Berlin stock market. The second half of the 1890s saw the beginning of a new period of expansion at Deutsche Bank. The bank formed alliances with large regional banks, giving itself an entry into Germany's main industrial regions. Joint ventures were symptomatic of the concentration then under way in the German banking industry. For Deutsche Bank, domestic branches of its own were still something of a rarity at the time; the Frankfurt branchHistorische Gesellschaft der Deutschen Bank (ed.), Die Deutsche Bank in Frankfurt am Main, Munich, Zurich (Piper) 2005. dated from 1886 and the Munich branch from 1892, while further branches were established in Dresden and LeipzigManfred Pohl / Angelika Raab-Rebentisch, Die Deutsche Bank in Leipzig 1901–2001, Munich, Zurich (Piper) 2001. in 1901. In addition, the bank rapidly perceived the value of specialist institutions for the promotion of foreign business. Gentle pressure from the Foreign Ministry played a part in the establishment of Deutsche Ueberseeische BankManfred Pohl, Deutsche Bank Buenos Aires 1887–1987, Mainz (v. Hase & Koehler) 1987. in 1886 and the stake taken in the newly established Deutsch-Asiatische BankMaximilian Müller-Jabusch, 50 Jahre Deutsch-Asiatische Bank 1890–1939, Berlin 1940. three years later, but the success of those companies showed that their existence made sound commercial sense. ===1919–1933=== [[File:Deutsche Bank und Disconto-Gesellschaft 1932.jpg|thumb|Share of the Deutschen Bank und Disconto-Gesellschaft, issued March 1932]] [[File:Ehemaliger-Gebaeudekomplex-der-Deutschen-Bank-Block-1-Franzoesische-Str-Ecke-Glinkastr-Berlin-Mitte-Apr-2016.jpg|thumb|Former Deutsche Bank building complex, corner of Französische Strasse and Glinkastrasse in [[Berlin]]]] In 1919, the bank purchased the state's share of Universum Film Aktiengesellschaft (Ufa).{{Cite book |last1=Plumpe |first1=Werner |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UIfQDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT299 |title=Deutsche Bank: The Global Hausbank, 1870 – 2020 |last2=Nützenadel |first2=Alexander |last3=Schenk |first3=Catherine |date=2020-03-05 |publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing |isbn=978-1-4729-7730-4 |pages=299 |language=en}} In 1926, the bank assisted in the merger of Daimler and Benz.{{Cite book |last1=Whittington |first1=Richard |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TnqH2fxnRlcC&pg=PA97 |title=The European Corporation: Strategy, Structure, and Social Science |last2=Mayer |first2=Michael |date=2002 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-925104-9 |pages=97 |language=en}} The bank merged with other local banks in 1929 to create Deutsche Bank and [[Disconto-Gesellschaft]].{{Cite news |date=1929-09-27 |title=TWO LEADING BANKS COMBINE IN BERLIN; Deutsche and Disconto Gesellschaft Form Biggest of Kind in German History.285,000,000-MARK CAPITALCombined Deposits 4,000,000,000----Believed Forerunner of OtherFinancial Consolidations. Announcement of Merger. One Employed 14,000 Persons. |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1929/09/27/archives/two-leading-banks-combine-in-berlin-deutsche-and-disconto.html |access-date=2020-04-17 |issn=0362-4331}} In 1937, the company name changed back to Deutsche Bank.{{Cite news |date=1937-09-09 |title=Deutsche Bank Resumes Name |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1937/09/09/archives/deutsche-bank-resumes-name.html |access-date=2020-04-17 |issn=0362-4331}} ===1933–1945=== After [[Adolf Hitler]] came to power, instituting the [[Third Reich]], Deutsche Bank dismissed its three [[Jewish]] board members in 1933.{{Cite news |last=Mitchener |first=Brandon |date=1995-02-22 |title=Deutsche Bank Admits It Helped Hitler : Confronting a Dark Past |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/22/business/worldbusiness/IHT-deutsche-bank-admits-it-helped-hitler-confronting.html |access-date=2020-10-01 |issn=0362-4331}} In subsequent years, Deutsche Bank took part in the [[Aryanization (Nazism)|aryanization]] of Jewish-owned businesses, provided the owners of “aryanized” businesses were in the know about their Jewish status beforehand; according to its own historians, the bank was involved in 363 such confiscations by November 1938.{{Cite web |title=Geschichte – Deutsche Bank |url=https://www.db.com/company/de/geschichte.htm |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050303033629/http://www.deutsche-bank.de/geschichte/en/html/index_c.htm |archive-date=3 March 2005 |website=db.com}} In 1938, German bank [[Mendelssohn & Co.]] was acquired.{{Cite news |last=Feuer |first=Alan |date=2007-12-18 |title=A Lawsuit Will Determine the Fate of 2 Picassos |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/18/nyregion/18picasso.html |access-date=2020-10-01 |issn=0362-4331}}{{Cite book |last1=Plumpe |first1=Werner |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UIfQDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT352 |title=Deutsche Bank: The Global Hausbank, 1870 – 2020 |last2=Nützenadel |first2=Alexander |last3=Schenk |first3=Catherine |date=2020-03-05 |publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing |isbn=978-1-4729-7730-4 |pages=352 |language=en}} During the war, Deutsche Bank incorporated other banks that fell into German hands during the occupation of Eastern Europe. Deutsche Bank provided banking facilities for the [[Gestapo]] and loaned the funds used to build the [[Auschwitz]] camp and the nearby [[IG Farben]] facilities.{{Cite news |last=Schmid |first=John |date=5 February 1999 |title=Deutsche Bank Linked To Auschwitz Funding |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/05/news/05iht-berlin.t.html |access-date=28 January 2010}} During World War II, Deutsche Bank became responsible for managing the Bohemian Union Bank in [[Prague]], with branches in the [[Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia|Protectorate]] and in [[Slovakia]], the Bankverein in [[Yugoslavia]] (which has now{{when|date=September 2021}} been divided into two financial corporations, one in [[Serbia]] and one in [[Croatia]]), the Albert de Barry Bank in [[Amsterdam]], the [[National Bank of Greece]] in Athens, the [[Creditanstalt]]-Bankverein in Austria and Hungary, the Deutsch-Bulgarische Kreditbank in [[Bulgaria]], and Banca Comercială Română ''(The Romanian Commercial Bank)'' in [[Bucharest]]. It also maintained a branch in [[Istanbul]], Turkey. In 1999, Deutsche Bank confirmed officially that it had been involved in the Auschwitz camp. In December 1999, Deutsche, along with other major German companies, contributed to a US$5.2 billion compensation fund following lawsuits brought by Holocaust survivors;{{Cite web |date=15 December 2004 |title=$5.2 Billion German Settlement |url=http://treasurer.ca.gov/holocaust/germanbank.htm |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060908070905/http://www.treasurer.ca.gov/holocaust/germanbank.htm |archive-date=8 September 2006 |access-date=17 August 2011}}For a detailed account of Deutsche Bank's involvement with the Nazis see: Harold James. ''The Nazi Dictatorship and the Deutsche Bank.'' Cambridge University Press, 2004, 296 pp., {{ISBN|0-521-83874-6}}. U.S. officials had threatened to block Deutsche Bank's $10 billion purchase of [[Bankers Trust]], a major American bank, if it did not contribute to the fund.{{Cite web|title=BBC News {{!}} The Company File {{!}} Holocaust claims threaten bank merger|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/276309.stm|access-date=2021-01-23|website=news.bbc.co.uk}} The history of Deutsche Bank during the [[Second World War]] has since been documented by independent historians commissioned by the Bank. ===Post-World War II=== [[File:Deutsche-Bank-Otto-Suhr-Allee-Berlin-Charlottenburg-06-2017b.jpg|thumb|Highrise of the Deutsche Bank in Berlin, designed by Friedrich Koch and {{ill|Günter Hönow|de}}, 1966-1968]] Following Germany's defeat in [[World War II]], the Allied authorities, in 1948, ordered Deutsche Bank's break-up into regional banks.{{Cite book |last1=Lange |first1=Even |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qUmoDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT370 |title=Centres and Peripheries in Banking: The Historical Development of Financial Markets |last2=Olsson |first2=Ulf |last3=Fraser |first3=Iain L. |date=2016-12-05 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-351-95293-4 |pages=370–71 |language=en}} These regional banks were later consolidated into three major banks in 1952: Norddeutsche Bank AG; Süddeutsche Bank AG; and Rheinisch-Westfälische Bank AG. In 1957, these three banks merged to form Deutsche Bank AG with its headquarters in Frankfurt. In 1959, the bank entered retail banking by introducing small personal loans. In the 1970s, the bank pushed ahead with international expansion, opening new offices in new locations, such as [[Milan]] (1977), [[Moscow]], [[London]], [[Paris]], and [[Tokyo]]. In the 1980s, this continued when the bank paid U$603 million in 1986 to acquire [[Banca d'America e d'Italia]].{{Cite web |date=February 2018 |title=La bella banca |url=http://www.bankgeschichte.de/en/docs/Historische_Rundschau-38-engl-Web.pdf |website=Bankgeschichte.de}} In 1972, the bank established its ''Fiduciary Services Division'' which provides support to its [[Wealth management|private wealth division]].{{cite web |url=http://www.pwm.db.com/080403_FSD_Brochure.pdf |title=Private Wealth Management. Deutsche Bank: A passion to perform. Fiduciary Solutions |work=Deutsche Bank website |date=March 2008 |access-date=10 February 2021 |archive-date=18 April 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130418065426/http://www.pwm.db.com/080403_FSD_Brochure.pdf}} At 8:30 am on 30 November 1989, [[Alfred Herrhausen]], chairman of Deutsche Bank, was killed when a car that he was in exploded while he was traveling in the [[Frankfurt]] suburb of [[Bad Homburg]]. The [[Red Army Faction]] claimed responsibility for the blast.{{cite news |last=Boehmer |first=George |url=https://apnews.com/article/8e59e745748a723ef3e3c6be84d236c7 |title=West Germany's Most Powerful Banker Killed In Bomb Blast |work=[[Associated Press]] |date=30 November 1989 |access-date=2 July 2021}}{{cite news |last=Belton |first=Catherine |author-link=Catherine Belton |url=https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2020/06/20/vladimir-putin-dresden-kgb-330203 |title=Did Vladimir Putin Support Anti-Western Terrorists as a Young KGB Officer? Putin has sworn his time as a KGB officer in Dresden was uneventful. There's a lot of reason to doubt that claim. |work=[[Politico]] |date=20 June 2020 |access-date=2 July 2021}} In 1989, the first steps towards creating a significant investment-banking presence were taken with the acquisition of [[Morgan, Grenfell & Co.]], a UK-based investment bank which was renamed Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in 1994. In 1995 to greatly expand into international investments and money management, Deutsche Bank hired Edson Mitchell, a risk specialist from [[Merrill Lynch]], who hired two other former Merrill Lynch risk specialists Anshu Jain and William S. Broeksmit.[https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/30/business/dealbook/deutsche-bank-flew-and-fell-some-paid-a-high-price.html?_r=0 Deutsche Bank Flew and Fell. Some Paid a High Price.] By the mid-1990s, the buildup of a capital-markets operation had got underway with the arrival of a number of high-profile figures from major competitors. Ten years after the acquisition of Morgan Grenfell, the US firm [[Bankers Trust]] was added. Bankers Trust suffered losses during the [[1998 Russian financial crisis]] since it had a large position in Russian government bonds,{{Cite news |last=Moyer |first=Liz |date=30 October 2007 |title=Super-Size That Severance |work=[[Forbes]] |url=https://www.forbes.com/2007/10/30/merrill-severance-compensation-biz-wall-cx_lm_1031failure.html |access-date=12 December 2018}} but avoided financial collapse by being acquired by Deutsche Bank for $10 billion in November 1998.{{Cite news |last=Andrews |first=Edmund L. |author-link=Edmund L. Andrews |date=1 December 1998 |title=Bank Giant: The Overview; Deutsche Gets Bankers Trust for $10 Billion |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/01/business/bank-giant-the-overview-deutsche-gets-bankers-trust-for-10-billion.html?pagewanted=all |access-date=12 December 2018}} On 4 June 1999, Deutsche Bank merged its Deutsche Morgan Grenfell and Bankers Trust to became Deutsche Asset Management (DAM) with Robert Smith as the CEO.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/361454.stm Morgan Grenfell bites the dust] BBC News, 4 June 1999. This made Deutsche Bank the fourth-largest money management firm in the world after [[UBS]], [[Fidelity Investments]], and the Japanese post office's life insurance fund. At the time, Deutsche Bank owned a 12% stake in [[DaimlerChrysler]] but United States banking laws prohibit banks from owning industrial companies, so Deutsche Bank received an exception to this prohibition through 1978 legislation from Congress. Deutsche continued to build up its presence in Italy with the acquisition in 1993 of [[Banca Popolare di Lecco]] from [[Banca Popolare di Novara]] for about $476 million.{{Cite news |last=Reuters |date=1993-11-27 |title=Company News; Deutsche Bank Announces Big Expansion in Italy |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/11/27/business/company-news-deutsche-bank-announces-big-expansion-in-italy.html |access-date=2019-10-31 |issn=0362-4331}} In 1999, it acquired a minority interest in [[Cassa di Risparmio di Asti]]. ===21st century=== In the [[September 11 attacks|11 September 2001 terrorist attacks]] the [[Deutsche Bank Building]] in [[Lower Manhattan]], formerly Bankers Trust Plaza, was heavily damaged by the collapse of the South Tower of the World Trade Center.{{Cite web |date=2014-05-02 |title=The Deutsche Bank building: Tombstone at Ground Zero – Mar. 20, 2008 |url=https://money.cnn.com/2008/03/19/news/companies/ground_zero.fortune/?postversion=2008032004 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502005224/https://money.cnn.com/2008/03/19/news/companies/ground_zero.fortune/?postversion=2008032004 |archive-date=2014-05-02 |access-date=2019-07-15}} Demolition work on the 39-story building continued for nearly a decade, and was completed in early 2011.{{Cite web |date=2011-03-28 |title=Lower Manhattan : 130 Liberty Street |url=http://www.lowermanhattan.info/construction/project_updates/130_liberty_street__77170.aspx |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110328045518/http://www.lowermanhattan.info/construction/project_updates/130_liberty_street__77170.aspx |archive-date=2011-03-28 |access-date=2019-07-15}} In October 2001, Deutsche Bank was listed on the [[New York Stock Exchange]]. This was the first NYSE listing after interruption due to [[11 September attacks]]. The following year, Josef Ackermann became CEO of Deutsche Bank and served as CEO until 2012 when he became involved with the [[Bank of Cyprus]].{{Cite news |last=Brinded |first=Lianna |date=11 November 2014 |title=Bank of Cyprus Funded and Controlled by Ex-KGB, Billionaires and Controversial Former Financiers |work=International Business Times UK |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/bank-cyprus-funded-controlled-by-ex-kgb-billionaires-former-rbs-deutsche-bank-financiers-1474198 |access-date=17 December 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150812205910/http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/bank-cyprus-funded-controlled-by-ex-kgb-billionaires-former-rbs-deutsche-bank-financiers-1474198 |archive-date=12 August 2015}}{{Cite news |last1=Protess |first1=Ben |last2=Silver-Greenberg |first2=Jessica |last3=Drucker |first3=Jesse |date=19 July 2017 |title=Big German Bank, Key to Trump's Finances, Faces New Scrutiny |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/19/business/big-german-bank-key-to-trumps-finances-faces-new-scrutiny.html |access-date=17 December 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170720003726/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/19/business/big-german-bank-key-to-trumps-finances-faces-new-scrutiny.html |archive-date=20 July 2017}} Then, beginning in 2002, Deutsche Bank strengthened its U.S. presence when it purchased Scudder Investments.{{Cite web |title=Scudder PIC joins Deutsche Bank's private banking |url=https://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/stories/2002/06/24/daily10.html |access-date=2019-10-31 |website=bizjournals.com}} Meanwhile, in Europe, Deutsche Bank increased its private-banking business by acquiring Rued Blass & Cie (2002) and the Russian investment bank United Financial Group (2005) founded by the United States banker Charles Ryan and the Russian official [[Boris Fyodorov]] which followed [[Anshu Jain]]'s aggressive expansion to gain strong relationships with state partners in Russia.{{Cite news |last=Harding |first=Luke |author-link=Luke Harding |date=21 December 2017 |title=Is Donald Trump's Dark Russian Secret Hiding in Deutsche Bank's Vaults? |work=[[Newsweek]] |url=https://www.newsweek.com/2017/12/29/donald-trump-russia-secret-deutsche-bank-753780.html |access-date=17 December 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181109121942/https://www.newsweek.com/2017/12/29/donald-trump-russia-secret-deutsche-bank-753780.html |archive-date=9 November 2018}}{{Cite news |last=Sampathkumar |first=Mythili |date=14 April 2017 |title=Former MI6 chief Richard Dearlove says Donald Trump borrowed money from Russia during 2008 financial crisis: Days before taking office, Mr Trump said Russia had never had any 'levarage' over him |work=[[The Independent]] |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/richard-dearlove-mi6-trump-russia-money-2008-financial-crisis-us-election-a7684341.html |access-date=17 December 2018 The 2011 US Senate Permanent Select Committee on Investigations report on "Wall Street and the Financial Crisis" analyzed Deutsche Bank as a case study of investment banking involvement in the mortgage bubble, CDO market, credit crunch, and recession. It concluded that even as the market was collapsing in 2007, and its top global CDO trader was deriding the CDO market and betting against some of the mortgage bonds in its CDOs, Deutsche bank continued to churn out bad CDO products to investors.{{Cite web |date=13 April 2011 |title=WALL STREET AND THE FINANCIAL CRISIS: Anatomy of a Financial Collapse | url=https://www.hsgac.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/PSI%20REPORT%20-%20Wall%20Street%20&%20the%20Financial%20Crisis-Anatomy%20of%20a%20Financial%20Collapse%20(FINAL%205-10-11).pdf |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110505035617/http://levin.senate.gov/newsroom/supporting/2011/PSI_WallStreetCrisis_041311.pdf |archive-date=5 May 2011 |website=US Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations |df=dmy-all}} The report focused on one CDO, Gemstone VII, made largely of mortgages from Long Beach, Fremont, and New Century, all notorious subprime lenders. Deutsche Bank put risky assets into the CDO, like ACE 2006-HE1 M10, which its own traders thought was a bad bond. It also put in some mortgage bonds that its own mortgage department had created but could not sell, from the DBALT 2006 series. The CDO was then aggressively marketed as a good product, with most of it being described as having A level ratings. By 2009 the entire CDO was almost worthless and the investors (including Deutsche Bank itself) had lost most of their money. [[Greg Lippmann]], head of global CDO trading, was betting against the CDO market, with approval of management, even as Deutsche was continuing to churn out product. He was a major character in Michael Lewis' book ''[[The Big Short]]'', which detailed his efforts to find 'shorts' to buy [[Credit Default Swaps]] (CDS) for the construction of [[Synthetic CDO]]s. He was one of the first traders to foresee the bubble in the CDO market as well as the tremendous potential that CDS offered in this. As portrayed in ''The Big Short'', Lipmann in the middle of the CDO and MBS frenzy was orchestrating presentations to investors, demonstrating his bearish view of the market, offering them the idea to start buying CDS, especially to [[American International Group|AIG]] in order to profit from the forthcoming collapse. As regards the Gemstone VII deal, even as Deutsche was creating and selling it to investors, Lippman emailed colleagues that it 'blew', and he called parts of it 'crap' and 'pigs' and advised some of his clients to bet against the mortgage securities it was made of. Lippman called the CDO market a 'ponzi scheme', but also tried to conceal some of his views from certain other parties because the bank was trying to sell the products he was calling 'crap'. Lippman's group made money off of these bets, even as Deutsche overall lost money on the CDO market. Deutsche was also involved with [[Magnetar Capital]] in creating its first Orion CDO. Deutsche had its own group of bad CDOs called START. It worked with Elliot Advisors on one of them; Elliot bet against the CDO even as Deutsche sold parts of the CDO to investors as good investments. Deutsche also worked with John Paulson, of the [[Goldman Sachs]] Abacus CDO controversy, to create some START CDOs. Deutsche lost money on START, as it did on Gemstone. On 3 January 2014, it was reported that Deutsche Bank would settle a lawsuit brought by US shareholders, who had accused the bank of bundling and selling bad real estate loans before the 2008 downturn. This settlement came subsequent and in addition to Deutsche's $1.93 billion settlement with the US Housing Finance Agency over similar litigation related to the sale of mortgage-backed securities to [[Fannie Mae]] and [[Freddie Mac]].{{Cite news |date=3 January 2014 |title=Deutsche Bank Settles with US Shareholders | work=[[MarketWatch]] |url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/deutsche-bank-settles-with-us-shareholders-2014-01-03}} ==== Leveraged super-senior trades ==== Former employees including Eric Ben-Artzi and Matthew Simpson have claimed that, during the crisis, Deutsche failed to recognize up to $12 billion of paper losses on its $130 billion portfolio of leveraged [[Senior debt#Super-senior status|super senior]] trades, although the bank rejects the claims.{{Cite news |last1=Braithwaite |first1=Tom |last2=Scannell |first2=Kara |last3=Mackenzie |first3=Michael |date=5 December 2012 |title=Deutsche hid up to $12bn losses, say staff |work=Financial Times |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/f03eb1d6-3efd-11e2-a095-00144feabdc0.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20221210/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/f03eb1d6-3efd-11e2-a095-00144feabdc0.html |archive-date=10 December 2022 |url-access=subscription}} A company document of May 2009 described the trades as "the largest risk in the trading book",{{Cite news |last1=Braithwaite |first1=Tom |last2=Mackenzie |first2=Michael |last3=Scannell |first3=Kara |date=5 December 2012 |title=Deutsche Bank: Show of strength or a fiction? |work=[[Financial Times]] |url=https://www.ft.com/content/f03eb1d6-3efd-11e2-a095-00144feabdc0 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20221210/https://www.ft.com/content/f03eb1d6-3efd-11e2-a095-00144feabdc0 |archive-date=10 December 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live}} and the whistleblowers allege that had the bank accounted properly for its positions its capital would have fallen to the extent that it might have needed a government bailout. One of them claims that "If Lehman Brothers didn't have to mark its books for six months it might still be in business, and if Deutsche had marked its books it might have been in the same position as Lehman." Deutsche had become the biggest operator in this market, which were a form of credit derivative designed to behave like the most senior tranche of a CDO. Deutsche bought insurance against default by [[Blue chip (stock market)|blue-chip companies]] from investors, mostly Canadian pension funds, who received a stream of insurance premiums as income in return for posting a small amount of collateral. The bank then sold protection to US investors via the CDX [[Credit default swap index|credit index]], the spread between the two was tiny but was worth $270m over the 7 years of the trade. It was considered very unlikely that many blue chips would have problems at the same time, so Deutsche required collateral of just 10% of the contract value. The risk of Deutsche taking large losses if the collateral was wiped out in a crisis was called the gap option. Ben-Artzi claims that after modeling came up with "economically unfeasible" results, Deutsche accounted for the gap option first with a simple 15% "haircut" on the trades (described as inadequate by another employee in 2006) and then in 2008 by a $1–2bn reserve for the credit correlation desk designed to cover all risks, not just the gap option. In October 2008, it stopped modeling the gap option and just bought S&P put options to guard against further market disruption, but one of the whistleblowers has described this as an inappropriate hedge. A model from Ben-Artzi's previous job at Goldman Sachs suggested that the gap option was worth about 8% of the value of the trades, worth $10.4bn. Simpson claims that traders were not simply understating the gap option but actively [[mismarking]] the value of their trades. ====European debt crisis, 2009–today==== {{Main|European debt crisis}} In 2008, Deutsche Bank reported its first annual loss in five decades,{{Cite news |title=Deutsche Bank in line for annual loss |url=https://www.ft.com/content/4f1f0ecc-e21d-11dd-b1dd-0000779fd2ac |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20221210/https://www.ft.com/content/4f1f0ecc-e21d-11dd-b1dd-0000779fd2ac |archive-date=10 December 2022 |website=[[Financial Times]] |date=14 January 2009 | url-access=subscription}} despite receiving billions of dollars from its insurance arrangements with [[AIG]], including US$11.8 billion from funds provided by US [[taxpayers]] to bail out AIG.{{Cite web |last=Javers | first=Eamon |title=AIG ships billions in bailout abroad |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2009/03/aig-ships-billions-in-bailout-abroad-020039 | work=[[Politico]] |date=15 March 2009 }} Based on a preliminary estimation from the [[European Banking Authority]] (EBA), in late 2011, Deutsche Bank AG needed to raise capital of about €3.2 billion as part of a required 9% core Tier 1 ratio after sovereign debt write-down starting in mid-2012.{{Cite news | url=https://www.afr.com/markets/eu-banks-slip-down-a-fire-sale-trail-20111214-i458i | title=EU banks slip down a fire sale trail | first1=Anne-Sylvaine |last1=Chassany | first2=Kevin | last2=Crowley | first3=Charles |last3=Penty | work=[[Australian Financial Review]] | date=December 14, 2011}} As of 2012, Deutsche Bank had negligible exposure to [[Greece]], but Spain and Italy accounted for a tenth of its European private and corporate banking business with credit risks of about €18 billion in Italy and €12 billion in Spain.{{Cite news |last=Böll, Sven; As of 2016, the bank was involved in some 7,800 legal disputes and calculated €5.4 billion as litigation reserves,{{Cite web |title=Deutsche Bank: Neuer Skandal | Börse Aktuell |url=http://boerse.ard.de/aktien/deutsche-bank-zwischen-ramsch-und-skandalen100.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170404093959/http://boerse.ard.de/aktien/deutsche-bank-zwischen-ramsch-und-skandalen100.html |archive-date=4 April 2017 |access-date=28 March 2017 |website=Boerse.ARD.de |df=dmy-all}} with a further €2.2 billion held against other contingent liabilities. According to the ''New Yorker'', Deutsche Bank has long had an "abject" reputation. Between 2008 and 2016, Deutsche Bank paid around nine billion dollars in fines and settlements related to wrongdoings across different issue areas. The [[FinCEN Files|FinCEN file]] leaks documented around $1.3 trillion of suspicious transactions through Deutsche Bank between 1999 and 2017. More than half of all suspicious transactions involving major banks in the FinCEN files leaks involved Deutsche Bank. ===Role in financial crisis of 2007–2008=== {{see also|Financial crisis of 2007–2008}} In January 2017, Deutsche Bank agreed to a $7.2 billion settlement with the [[United States Department of Justice]] over its sale and pooling of toxic mortgage securities in the years leading up to the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2008]]. As part of the agreement, Deutsche Bank was required to pay a civil monetary penalty of $3.1 billion and provide $4.1 billion in consumer relief, such as loan forgiveness. At the time of the agreement, Deutsche Bank was still facing investigations into the alleged manipulation of foreign exchange rates, suspicious equities trades in Russia, as well as alleged violations of [[United States sanctions against Iran]] and other countries. Since 2012, Deutsche Bank had paid more than €12 billion for litigation, including a deal with U.S. mortgage-finance giants [[Fannie Mae]] and [[Freddie Mac]].{{Cite news |last=Freifeld |first=Karen |title=Deutsche Bank agrees to $7.2 billion mortgage settlement with U.S. |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-deutsche-bank-mortgages-settlement-idUSKBN14C041 |access-date=13 January 2017 |website=Reuters|date=23 December 2016 }} ===Espionage scandal, 2009=== In 2009, the bank admitted it engaged in covert espionage on its critics from 2001 to 2007 directed by its corporate security department, although it characterized the incidents as "isolated".{{Cite news |last1=Crawford |first1=David |last2=Karnitschnig |first2=Matthew |date=3 August 2009 |title=Bank Spy Scandal Widens |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB124925060899599929 |access-date=27 January 2010}} According to ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', Deutsche Bank had prepared a list of names of people who it wanted investigated for criticism of the bank, including [[Michael Bohndorf]] (an activist investor in the bank), [[Leo Kirch]] (a former media executive in litigation with the bank), and the Munich law firm of [[Bub Gauweiler & Partner]], which represented Kirch. According to the ''Wall Street Journal'', the bank's legal department was involved in the scheme along with its corporate security department. The bank hired [[Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton]] to investigate the incidents on its behalf. The Cleary firm submitted its report, which however was not made public. According to ''The Wall Street Journal'', the Cleary firm uncovered a plan by which Deutsche Bank was to infiltrate the Bub Gauweiler firm by having a bank [[Mole (espionage)|mole]] hired as an intern at the Bub Gauweiler firm.
